_header: Now welcome summer with thy sun soft
Subjects: roundels; birds, as narrators; birds; songs
_description: A roundel (‘Qui bien aimé a tard oubliè’) inserted in two MSS of Chaucer’s Parlement of Foules (5373) between stanzas 97 and 98 — thirteen lines

OxfStJohn57.Transcription:
Seynt Valentyn þat art full hiȝe on lofftThus syngen smale
                    foulis for thy sakeWele have þey cause forto glat offtSith eche
                    of hem recoverid hath his makefful blesfull may they syng when þey
                    wake
OxfStJohn57.Note:
One incomplete stanza only, inserted between stanzas 97 and 98 of
                    Chaucer’s Parliament of Fouls; introduced by stanza 97: ‘But
                    furst were chosen foulis forto syng / As yeer be yeer was alwey hir vsaunce / To
                    syng a ryndell at hir departyng / To do nature honour & plesaunce / The note
                    I trowe was made in ffraunce / The wordis were such as yee may here fynde / The
                    next vers as I have nowe in mynde’, and followed by stanza 98: ‘And
                    with the showtyng when þe song was doon…’.
OxfStJohn57.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CULGg427.First Lines:
Nowe welcome somore with sonne softeThat hast thes wintres wedres
                    ovire shake…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Sethe ech of hem recordede hathe hys makefful blisseful nowe
                    they ben when they wake
CULGg427.Note:
Inserted as penultimate stanza to Parlement of Fowles by another
                    hand of the fifteenth century in space left for insertion by original
                    scribe.

BodDig181.First Lines:
Nowe well come somer with thy sonne softeThat hast this wynter
                    wedirs ouer shake…
BodDig181.Last Lines:
…Sith eche of them recouered hath his makeffull blisfully they
                    synge and endles ioy þei make
BodDig181.Note:
Fragment: 7 lines only; inserted as penultimate stanza to Parlement
                        of Fowles.
